== Biography çµæ­´ ==
== Biography çµæ­´ ==
â
[[Image:Kyoko_Okazaki.jpg|thumb|100px|Kyoko Okazaki]]
 
Okazaki grew up in Tokyo in a large household, of around fifteen people. Okazaki's father was a talented barber. The whole family lived together: grandparents, uncles and aunts, cousins and even apprentice hairdressers. Though Okazaki lived happy and peaceful, she failed to feel completely comfortable in this family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://66.102.1.102/translate_c?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://clio.revues.org/index649.html&prev=/search%3Fq%3Dpink%2Bokazaki%2Bkyoko%26hl%3Den%26safe%3Doff%26sa%3DG%26pwst%3D1&usg=ALkJrhj9lcVRkF6eFRi7vLlBdmVIxtENIQ|title=Early life}}</ref>
Okazaki grew up in Tokyo in a large household, of around fifteen people. Okazaki's father was a talented barber. The whole family lived together: grandparents, uncles and aunts, cousins and even apprentice hairdressers. Though Okazaki lived happy and peaceful, she failed to feel completely comfortable in this family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://66.102.1.102/translate_c?hl=en&sl=fr&u=http://clio.revues.org/index649.html&prev=/search%3Fq%3Dpink%2Bokazaki%2Bkyoko%26hl%3Den%26safe%3Doff%26sa%3DG%26pwst%3D1&usg=ALkJrhj9lcVRkF6eFRi7vLlBdmVIxtENIQ|title=Early life}}</ref>
In 1983, while studying in [[Atomi University]], Okazaki made her debut in ''Cartoon Burikko'', an erotic manga magazine primarily aimed for male adults. In 1985, while still a university student, she also published her first manga, ''Virgin''. After this, Okazaki wrote ''Pink'' in 1989, which firmly established her reputation. Other early published works include ''Tokyo Girls Bravo'' in ''CUTIE'' (a monthly Japanese fashion magazine).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=L6ta_zRaVP8C&pg=RA2-PA204&lpg=RA2-PA204&dq=okazaki+kyoko+pink,+which+established&source=web&ots=iwv43fA-P2&sig=w3UdPpPQ6Id0Bp5XA2Bowlw7ah0&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=7&ct=result|title=1980s manga}}</ref> In 1994, Okazaki put on a solo exhibition at the grand opening of the experimental art space, P-House, in Tokyo. From 1993 to 1994, she did a serialization called ''River's Edge'', in which she portrayed the conflicts and problems experienced by high-schoolers living in a Tokyo suburb; the series had a big influence on the literary world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arttowermito.or.jp/life/life.html|title=1990s manga}}</ref>
In 1983, while studying in [[Atomi University]], Okazaki made her debut in ''Cartoon Burikko'', an erotic manga magazine primarily aimed for male adults. In 1985, while still a university student, she also published her first manga, ''Virgin''. After this, Okazaki wrote ''Pink'' in 1989, which firmly established her reputation. Other early published works include ''Tokyo Girls Bravo'' in ''CUTIE'' (a monthly Japanese fashion magazine).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=L6ta_zRaVP8C&pg=RA2-PA204&lpg=RA2-PA204&dq=okazaki+kyoko+pink,+which+established&source=web&ots=iwv43fA-P2&sig=w3UdPpPQ6Id0Bp5XA2Bowlw7ah0&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=7&ct=result|title=1980s manga}}</ref> In 1994, Okazaki put on a solo exhibition at the grand opening of the experimental art space, P-House, in Tokyo. From 1993 to 1994, she did a serialization called ''River's Edge'', in which she portrayed the conflicts and problems experienced by high-schoolers living in a Tokyo suburb; the series had a big influence on the literary world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arttowermito.or.jp/life/life.html|title=1990s manga}}</ref>
